The viewport size function on this page is wrong. Here is the corrected way to get the viewport consistently, and sans any visible scrollbar(s):

https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=156388#c14
https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=189112#c7

I think your pageSize() is incorrect in some scenarios, because it is relying on window.innerWidth/Height, which will include the size of any visible scroll bars. As long as the DOCTYPE is declared Transistional, then ScrollWidth/Height is sufficient:

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1091048/alternatives-to-window-scrollmaxy/1732727#1732727

Also it is incorrect to say that we can not detect the scrollbar sizes in all browsers other than IE, as this is window.innerwidth/Height – document.(body or documentElement).clientWidth/Height. Also we can detect the scroll bar sizes in IE also, but I will leave this for you to figure out.

You could use this code to set a wrapper div to the exact width and height of the browser view port, but that isn’t what I would recommend.

The best way to support small screens is elastic design using nothing but CSS. There are many good tutorials out there on elastic design, but the technique is basically to use percentage and em measurements for the layout instead of pixels.

If you really do need to be able to update some styles via JavaScript to fit the screen you can use the code from this article. Here’s an example:

Let’s say that you want to adjust the width on a wrapper div, here’s what your document may look like:

<div id="wrapper">
	<!-- your content here -->
</div>

Then this script will target the markup above and fit it to the screen:

function fitWrapperToScreen() {
	sb_windowTools.updateDimensions();
	var div = document.getElementById('wrapper'); 
	div.style.width = sb_windowTools.pageDimensions.windowWidth() + 'px';
	div.style.height = sb_windowTools.pageDimensions.windowHeight() + 'px';
}

Again, this should be done with elastic techniques. You could skip all of this and get a better effect with the following CSS:

#wrapper {
	width: 100%;
	height: 100%;
}

If you needed to support other browsers there would probably be some extra issues, but I believe these should work fine in WebKit. If you are having a problem with your content pushing out the div just add overflow: hidden; or overflow: scroll;.
